document.docAuthor: Decru, E., Vreven, E. & Snoeks, J.
document.docTitle: Hepsetus akawo Decru & Vreven & Snoeks 2011, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: A revision of the West African Hepsetus (Characiformes: Hepsetidae) with a description of Hepsetus akawo sp. nov. and a redescription of Hepsetus odoe (Bloch, 1794)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A revision of the West African Hepsetus (Characiformes: Hepsetidae) with a description of Hepsetus akawo sp. nov. and a redescription of Hepsetus odoe (Bloch, 1794)

MRAC 80-16 -P-8; 221.0 mm; Asejura lake , Oshun riv., Dugbe market Ibadan (

,

Hepsetus akawo
can be distinguished from all other
Hepsetus species
by the following unique combination of characters: number of lateral line scales, low: 43–51; nostril-lower jaw distance, short: 36.6–42.1 (mean 39.6) % HL (Figure 3); number of gill rakers, high: 17–23; number of scales between dorsal fin and lateral line: 71 / 2 – 91 / 2 number of scales between adipose fin and lateral line: 41 / 2 – 61 / 2 head width, broad: 32.8–42.3 (mean 37.0) % HL; and internasal distance, high: 21.9–28.3 (mean 24.7) % HL.
The holotype is illustrated in Figure 6 . Maximum observed size: 277.5 mm SL. Meristic and morphometric data are given in respectively Table 5 and 6 .

Head broad but shallow, with a relatively long but broad snout. Body elongated and broad, which gives it a plump appearance. Dorsal and anal fins, though in a posterior position in all
Hepsetus species
, are more anteriorly positioned relatively to the other
Hepsetus .
Small number of lateral line scales and a large number of quite small gill rakers on the epibranchiale of the first gill arch.

Hepsetus akawo
can be distinguished from
H. odoe
by a smaller number of total lateral line scales [43–51 vs 50–60 (exceptionally 49)], and by a lower nostril-lower jaw distance [36.6–42.1 (mean 39.6) % HL vs 40.4–47.6 (42.6) % HL].

Hepsetus akawo
can be distinguished from
H. cuvieri
by a higher number of gill rakers (17–23 vs 8–13), a lower number of scales between dorsal fin and lateral line ( 71 / 2 – 91 / 2 vs 101 / 2 – 111 / 2 ); a lower number of scales between adipose fin and lateral line ( 41 / 2 – 61 / 2 vs 61 / 2 – 71 / 2 ); and by a broader head width: 32.8–42.3 (mean 37.0 % HL vs 27.8–40.4 (33.5) % HL; a larger interorbital distance 28.0–34.9 (mean 31.7) % HL vs 23.7–32.6 (28.2) % HL; and a larger internasal distance 21.9–28.3 (mean 24.7) % HL vs 18.0–26.8 (20.8) % HL. The latter three characters are positively allometric.

Dorsal side of head and body brownish, with a gradual change from darker to lighter tones on the flanks. Entirely yellowish ventrally. Some specimens darker brownish and more uniformly coloured. A vague horizontal line pattern on the flanks, from anterior border of adipose fin (occasionally from posterior border of dorsal fin) to caudal fin base, resulting from the scales having a darker upper and lower border, whereas the remaining part of the scales remains paler. These lines cover the flanks from approximately three scale rows above lateral line down to two scale rows below the lateral line. Sometimes series of 10 to 16 greyish vertical bands are present on the dorsolateral body parts. The presence of these bands appears to be linked to stress (personal observation). Rounded dorsoventrally elongated blackish spot behind head and just above lateral line.

caption.paragraph:
Figure 6. Lateral view of
Hepsetus akawo
, holotype, MRAC 73-5-P-465, 211.5 mm standard length, Anecho lagune, Togo.

subSubSection.paragraph: Posterior part of head with three, well-marked, dark brownish bands running from posterior border of the eye to anterior edge of preopercle. Bands sometimes faded and poorly visible. Lower half of postopercle brownish, sometimes blackish. Rounded dorsoventrally elongated blackish spot behind the head, above the lateral line.

All fins but the adipose fin yellowish to dark brownish (more or less the same as body colour); distally translucent. Caudal fin translucent, in mid-centre and proximally on upper and lower lobes. Dorsal, anal and caudal fins with prominent small, roundish, dark-brown spots. Spots on fins more prominent on larger specimens (±> 150 mm SL). Adipose fin base yellowish to darker brownish, black distally.

caption.paragraph:
Table 5. Meristics for the holotype, paratypes and all examined specimens of
Hepsetus akawo
sp. nov.

tr.td: Gill rakers on first gill arch

caption.paragraph:
Table 6. Measurements for the holotype, paratypes and all examined specimens of
Hepsetus akawo
sp. nov.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Within West Africa,
H. akawo
is restricted to the easternmost part of the region, i.e. from the Sassandra River ( Ivory Coast ) in the west to the Shari River ( Central African Republic ) in the east and the Cross River ( Cameroon / Nigeria ) in the southeast

The specific name refers to the local names in the Adangme language of
Hepsetus
specimens in Ghana : “ Akawo nyagbe ”, which means “dog-like teeth” and “
akawo
” which means “attacker” or “predator” ( Dankwa 2003 ).
